Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Behavioral type - environment correlations in three-spined stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Consistent individual differences in behavior, analogous to personality in humans, are ubiquitous throughout the animal kingdom. Animals can serve as models to study the evolutionary and ecological causes and consequences of personality in ways that are not possible in human psychology. For example, researchers interested in differences in boldness, aggression, and exploratory behavior have studied a fish, named the three-spined stickleback, that has a relatively short lifespan and is easy to care for. Previous studies have shown that different personalities of three-spined stickleback occur in different habitats and social environments in nature. The goal of this project is to determine 1) whether the personality of an individual is shaped by their environment, i.e. via plasticity; 2) if certain personalities consistently use certain environments over time (for example, if bold individuals always occur in large social groups); and 3) whether individuals tend to occur in environments for which they are well-suited. The project comprises an intensive laboratory-based experiment and a large-scale study of three-spined stickleback in their natural environment to provide a complete understanding of why some personalities are more likely to occur in certain habitats or social environments. This work has important implications for understanding why animals, including humans, show such marked variation in behavior that is consistent across time or context. This project provides ample training opportunities for undergraduates to become future scientists. The topic of the research, especially the field component, is highly accessible to a general audience and will be presented as science-in-action to local citizens and vacationers throughout the field season in rural Mendocino County, CA.

Data from this project will be made available in the Dryad Digital Repository (datadryad.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Populations of animals are often composed of individuals that differ consistently from one another in behavior. In humans, the name we use for consistent individual differences in behavior is personality. Although the traits we study in non-human animals differ from the well-known human traits, i.e. the “big five”, consistent individual differences in behavior in non-human animals have been dubbed animal personality.

 

A growing number of researchers are studying animal personality because it challenges the status quo notion that species are evolving a single optimal set of behaviors. Instead it is possible that a diverse set of behavioral types exist in nature because differences between individuals are actually adaptive. One way the coexistence of different behavioral types might happen is if individuals occur in environment to which they are best suited.  

 

We decided to test this hypothesis using a small fish species that goes by the name, three-spined stickleback. It occurs in marine and freshwater habitats throughout the Northern hemisphere. We picked this species because it is abundant and short-lived, meaning we could get a glimpse of a substantial portion of their lives. The other advantage of studying three-spined stickleback was that previous researchers had shown that individuals differ consistently in a trait that has the potential to affect survival; the trait commonly referred to as boldness reflects an individual’s willingness to take risks.

 

In previous research, we found that fish with relatively bold behavioral types were more likely to occur in open habitats rather than in vegetation and that they occurred in groups as opposed to occurring alone.  Relatively shy fish were more likely to be in vegetated habitats or they were usually alone. This observation in itself did not show that fish occurred in environments to which their behavior was well suited as it was strictly a correlation.

 

With a Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant from the National Science Foundation, we set out to find which environment best suited bold fish and which environment was better for shy individuals. We sampled the Navarro River in Northern California and collected data on the habitat, social environment, and personality type of individuals. We tagged individual fish with identification markings and returned them to the river. Two weeks later, we swept the river for survivors. The survival of relatively bold and shy fish did not differ across habitat types. However, we did find a difference across social environments. Bold fish were favored in groups and shy fish were more likely to survive if they occurred alone.

 

This project provided evidence that three-spined stickleback did, in fact, occur in environments to which their personality was well suited. Although more work is required to test alternative explanations, our research provides evidence that consistent individual differences in behavior aren’t just random noise around the species’ optimal behavior. Instead, differences in behavior might persist through time because they are actually adaptive.

 

The results of this project were presented orally at two meetings (Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology, Austin, TX 2014; American Society of Naturalists, Pacific Grove, CA 2014). Two manuscripts in preparation will be submitted for publication; one to the Journal of Fish Biology and another to Behavioral Ecology.
